text: The monster let out a deep growl, the rocky plates on its limbs glinting coldly. Its breath was hot and heavy, as if it could crush the whole forest beneath it.
I forced myself to stay calm, eyes fixed on its movements. It was fast and heavy, but each time it landed, its right foreleg hesitated slightly.
In that moment, I understood—that was its weak point.
“Alicia! Its right leg—there’s a crack there!” I shouted.

She reacted instantly, twisting her stance as her body flashed like silver light. Her blade struck cleanly at the crack. With a muffled impact, the creature froze mid-motion before collapsing, dissolving into a cloud of gray smoke.
I exhaled heavily, my legs still trembling. Alicia sheathed her sword, scanning the ground to ensure the creature was truly gone before turning back to me.
“That shout just saved my life,” she said with a faint smile. “Sharp eyes you’ve got there.”
“I… just got lucky.” I scratched my head awkwardly.
“Luck doesn’t tell you where a crack is.” She chuckled softly. “Next time you notice something like that, tell me sooner.”
The wind swept through the forest, carrying away the lingering smoke. Alicia’s gaze fell on the scorched earth, her expression turning solemn.
“These creatures aren’t natural,” she said quietly. “They’re ‘Residual Dreams’—the traces left behind by the dead.”
“Yes. In places where wars were fought and lives were lost, the ground absorbs their final emotions. Over time, those emotions take form.”
Her gaze softened as she looked at me. “You did well back there. Thank you.”
I smiled sheepishly. “That’s because you’re a good teacher.”
She laughed lightly. “I didn’t teach you that.”
She extended her hand, and I instinctively took it—the warmth of her palm still carried the heat of battle.
“You sure get comfortable fast. Come on, the market’s just ahead.”
Alicia smiled again, a soft, fleeting smile like sunlight filtering through the trees—warm and hard to look away from.
